sen.cmt: grammar ("in order that" cannot be used in this way)
sen.e: To accomplish this, the Meiji government, which was promoting the message of fukoku kyohei (rich country, strong military), focused on nurturing new industries and stepped up construction of various facilities including the silk mills of Tomioka.

sen.j: 開港場の居留地は、長く鎖国下にあった日本にとって西洋文明のショーウィンドーとなり、文明開化の拠点であった。
sen.e: The settlements in the opening port site played a role of store windows for Japan under national isolation, and they were spots of civilization and enlightenment.

The settlements in the opened ports were a sort of window into the wonders of the west for Japan, which had long been isolated from the world, and functioned as strongholds of enlightenment and civilization.

The settlements in the opened ports were a sort of window into the wonders of the west for Japan, which had long been isolated from the world, and functioned as strongholds of enlightenment and civilization.

sen.j: 西洋風の町並み、ホテル、教会堂、洋館はハイカラな文化の象徴となる。
sen.e: Western-Style townscape, hotels, churches, and Western-style houses were symbols of rakish culture.
These western-style towns with their hotels, churches, and western-style houses became symbols of fashionable ("high-collar") western culture.
These western-style towns with their hotels, churches, and western-style houses became symbols of fashionable ("high-collar") western culture.

sen.j: この居留地を中心として横浜、神戸の新しい市街地が形成され、浜っ子、神戸っ子のハイカラ文化が生み出されることになる。
sen.e: New urban area in Yokohama and Kobe were created around the settlements, rakish culture was born for the people living in Yokohama and Kobe.
New urban areas in Yokohama and Kobe sprang up around the settlements, and with that, high-collar western culture was born for the inhabitants of Yokohama and Kobe.
sen.cmt: grammar (this translator has major problems with singular vs. plural, etc.)
sen.e: New urban areas in Yokohama and Kobe sprang up around the settlements, and with that, high-collar western culture was born for the inhabitants of Yokohama and Kobe.

sen.j: 横浜居留地では、1862年から1887年まで25年にわたって『ジャパン・パンチ』が発行された。
sen.e: "The Japan Punch" was published in Yokohama settlement for 25 years from 1862 to 1887.
In Yokohama settlement a magazine called "The Japan Punch" began publication in 1862 and continued for 25 years, until 1887.
In Yokohama settlement a magazine called "The Japan Punch" began publication in 1862 and continued for 25 years, until 1887.

sen.j: この雑誌は、『イラストレイテッド・ロンドン・ニューズ』特派通信員として来日したチャールズ・ワーグマンが出版したもので、風刺漫画で有名である。
sen.e: This magazine was published by Charles Wirgman who came to Japan as a correspondent of "Illustrated London News", and famous for a cartoon.
This magazine was published by Charles Wirgman, who had come to Japan as a correspondent for the "Illustrated London News"; the Japan Punch became famous for its cartoons.
This magazine was published by Charles Wirgman, who had come to Japan as a correspondent for the "Illustrated London News"; the Japan Punch became famous for its cartoons.

sen.j: ジャパン・パンチによれば当時、人口2千人ほどの居留地外国人の楽しみは根岸競馬場での競馬観戦であり、テニスやラケットボール、クリケット（英国人）、野球（米国人）も人気があった。
sen.e: There were 2000 population in the settlement, and according to The Japan Punch, the foreigners enjoyed watching horse racing at Negishi Racetrack, and playing tennis, racket ball, cricket (the English), and baseball (the American) were also popular.

There were about 2000 people living in the settlement, and according to the Japan Punch, foreigners enjoyed watching horse racing at Negishi Racetrack; other popular sports included tennis, racket ball, cricket (among the English), and baseball (among the Americans).
sen.cmt: word choice (population cannot be used in this way)
sen.e: There were about 2000 people living in the settlement, and according to the Japan Punch, foreigners enjoyed watching horse racing at Negishi Racetrack; other popular sports included tennis, racket ball, cricket (among the English), and baseball (among the Americans).

sen.j: 多くのスポーツ競技も居留地から日本に伝わった。
sen.e: Many kinds of sports were introduced in Japan from the settlements.
Many kinds of sports were first introduced into Japan from the foreign settlements.
sen.cmt: This sentence is better with "first" in it.
sen.e: Many kinds of sports were first introduced into Japan from the foreign settlements.

sen.j: この他、横浜・神戸・長崎では英字新聞も発行されている。
sen.e: Moreover, English newspaper was published in Yokohama, Kobe and Nagasaki.
Moreover, English-language newspapers were published in Yokohama, Kobe and Nagasaki.
Moreover, English-language newspapers were published in Yokohama, Kobe and Nagasaki.

sen.j: 1861年より横浜居留地内で居留外国人によって西洋式の競馬が行われるようになり、1866年に横濱競馬場が建設された後は特に盛んとなった。
sen.e: The Western-style horse race was held by the settled foreigners in Yokohama settlement since 1861, and it became more flourished after Yokohama horse race track was established in 1866.

Western-style horse racing was first conducted by the foreigners living in Yokohama settlement beginning in 1861, and the practice flourished even more after the Yokohama horse-racing track was built in 1866.
sen.cmt: grammar ("became more flourished" is not an acceptable phrase)
sen.e: Western-style horse racing was first conducted by the foreigners living in Yokohama settlement beginning in 1861, and the practice flourished even more after the Yokohama horse-racing track was built in 1866.

sen.j: また、1868年から数年間、神戸居留地でも同様の競馬が行われた。
sen.e: Also the same kind of horse race was held in Kobe settlement for several years since 1868.
The same kind of horse race was also held in Kobe settlement for several years beginning in 1868.
The same kind of horse race was also held in Kobe settlement for several years beginning in 1868.

sen.j: このような競馬を居留地競馬といい、採用された競技方式の面において現在の日本競馬のルーツであるとされる。
sen.e: This kind of horse race was called Settlement horse race, and this was the root of the current horse race in Japan at the point of adopted competitive system.

This kind of horse racing was dubbed Settlement horse racing, and became the root of modern-day horse racing in Japan in the sense that the current system of competition was adopted from the Settlement racing system.

This kind of horse racing was dubbed Settlement horse racing, and became the root of modern-day horse racing in Japan in the sense that the current system of competition was adopted from the Settlement racing system.

tit.e: The Settlements and Overseas Chinese Residents
The Settlements and Overseas Chinese Residents

sen.j: 横浜、神戸、長崎では居留地の中（神戸は隣接地）に中華街が形成され、日本三大中華街に発展した。
sen.e: Chinatowns were established in the settlements in Yokohama, Kobe, and Nagasaki (in the neighborhood in Kobe), and they were developed to the three major China towns in Japan.

Chinatowns were founded in the settlements in Yokohama, Kobe, and Nagasaki (Kobe's Chinatown was founded on land adjoining the settlement); these three have developed into the three major Chinatowns in Japan today.
sen.cmt: grammar (no need for the passive voice here, and "chinatown" is one word)
sen.e: Chinatowns were founded in the settlements in Yokohama, Kobe, and Nagasaki (Kobe's Chinatown was founded on land adjoining the settlement); these three have developed into the three major Chinatowns in Japan today.

sen.j: これは当初来日する外国商人は中国の開港場から来る者が多く、日本は漢字が通用するので中国人買弁が通訳として同行してきたためである。
sen.e: The reason for that was many foreign merchants came to Japan from the opening port site in China at first, as Japanese people could understand the Chinese characters Chinese comprador accompanied the merchants as interpreter.

Chinatowns sprang up because at first most foreign merchants came to Japan from the treaty port concessions of China, and as Japanese people could understand written Chinese characters Chinese compradors accompanied the merchants as translators.
sen.cmt: Incomprehensible phrasing. Note also that although the original Japanese has "tsuuyaku" their role was really more of translation.
sen.e: Chinatowns sprang up because at first most foreign merchants came to Japan from the treaty port concessions of China, and as Japanese people could understand written Chinese characters Chinese compradors accompanied the merchants as translators.

sen.j: その後、日本と中国各地の開港場に定期船航路が開けると中国人商人（華僑）が独自に進出してきた。
sen.e: Afterwards, sea routs for the liner between Japan and every site of opening port in China were established, Chinese merchants (Kakyo [Chinese residents]) entered the market by themselves.

Thereafter, once sea routes for ocean liners between Japan and every treaty port in China were established, Chinese merchants (overseas Chinese, or "kakyo" in Japanese) entered the market by themselves.
sen.cmt: word choice (this translator consistently uses the phrase "opening port" but no such phrase exists)
sen.e: Thereafter, once sea routes for ocean liners between Japan and every treaty port in China were established, Chinese merchants (overseas Chinese, or "kakyo" in Japanese) entered the market by themselves.

sen.j: 中国人もオランダ人同様、長崎唐人屋敷で長年日本貿易を行ってきた歴史がある。
sen.e: In history Chinese as well as Dutch traded with Japan at Tojin yashiki in Nagasaki for a long period.
Historically, the Chinese, just like the Dutch, had been trading with the Japanese in Nagasaki for a very long time; their trading activities were conducted at the Tojin yashiki.
sen.cmt: grammar (structurally, it reads as though both the Chinese and the Dutch operated out of Tojin yashiki)
sen.e: Historically, the Chinese, just like the Dutch, had been trading with the Japanese in Nagasaki for a very long time; their trading activities were conducted at the Tojin yashiki.

sen.j: 神戸に進出した華僑は富裕な貿易商が多く、彼らは北野町とその西に居を構えた。
sen.e: Many of the Kakyo who entered Kobe were rich trade merchants, they settled in Kitanocho town and the Western side of it.
Many of the overseas Chinese who entered Kobe were wealthy traders; they settled in the town of Kitanocho and to the west of it.
Many of the overseas Chinese who entered Kobe were wealthy traders; they settled in the town of Kitanocho and to the west of it.

sen.j: これが神戸の関帝廟が例外的に神戸南京町から離れた山手の住宅地に存在する理由である。
sen.e: This is the reason why Kantei byo Shrine in Kobe was exceptionally moved from Kobe Nankin –machi (Kobe Chinatown) to the residential area in Yamate.
This is the reason why the unusual step was taken of moving Kantei byo Shrine in Kobe from Kobe Nankin–machi (Kobe's Chinatown) to the residential area in Yamate.
This is the reason why the unusual step was taken of moving Kantei byo Shrine in Kobe from Kobe Nankin–machi (Kobe's Chinatown) to the residential area in Yamate.

sen.j: 横浜に進出した華僑は、その大半が飲食業を営んだために、横浜中華街の面積が大きくなった。
sen.e: Most of the Kakyo who came to Yokohama managed restaurant business, the area of Yokohama Chinatown was expanded.
Most of the overseas Chinese who came to Yokohama ran restaurants, and as a result the area of the Chinatown in Yokohama expanded.
sen.cmt: word choice, grammar (this translator's default choice is the passive voice, which is the wrong choice 90% of the time in English)
sen.e: Most of the overseas Chinese who came to Yokohama ran restaurants, and as a result the area of the Chinatown in Yokohama expanded.

sen.j: 居留地は外国人を一ヶ所に集めて置けるので、日本人との紛争防止に役立つなど、日本政府にとって便利な面もあったが、やはり治外法権、領事裁判権を認める不平等条約の落とし子であり、国家的な体面から容認できないものであった。
sen.e: The settlement was convenient for the Japanese government, because they could settle the foreigners in one place and protect from the conflict between Japanese, but as it was a fruit of unequal treaty which admitted extraterritoriality and consular jurisdiction, they could not admit it from the point of national responsibility.

In many ways the settlements were quite convenient for the Japanese government, for example because they kept foreigners settled in certain specific places and thus helped prevent conflict with local Japanese, but as they were the fruit of the unequal treaties and demanded extraterritoriality and consular jurisdiction for their inhabitants, they were unacceptable with respect to national prestige.

In many ways the settlements were quite convenient for the Japanese government, for example because they kept foreigners settled in certain specific places and thus helped prevent conflict with local Japanese, but as they were the fruit of the unequal treaties and demanded extraterritoriality and consular jurisdiction for their inhabitants, they were unacceptable with respect to national prestige.

sen.j: このうち、列強側の維持費の都合から長崎では1876年、横浜では1877年に居留地の返還が行われたが、他の居留地は依然として継続された。
sen.e: As for the convenience of preservation cost of the powerful countries, the settlements were returned in 1876 in Nagasaki and in 1877 in Yokohama, however other settlements were still continued.

Among the various settlements, two were restored to Japanese sovereignty due to escalating maintenance costs for the great powers maintaining them, namely Nagasaki in 1876 and Yokohama in 1877, but the other settlements continued unchanged.

Among the various settlements, two were restored to Japanese sovereignty due to escalating maintenance costs for the great powers maintaining them, namely Nagasaki in 1876 and Yokohama in 1877, but the other settlements continued unchanged.

sen.j: このため明治政府は条約改正に努力したものの、逆に国粋主義者の一部には外国人を居留地に閉じ込めて、日本の伝統・文化を守るべきだと言う対外硬運動も起きて複雑な展開を見せることもあった。
sen.e: Although, Meiji government made an effort to revise the treaty, a part of nationalists developed a movement to insist the ｐrotection of Japanese tradition and culture by confining foreigners in the settlement, the complicated situation was expanded.

The Meiji government exerted great effort to revise the treaties in order to regain sovereignty over the remaining settlements, but one nationalist faction began a movement to insist that on the contrary, Japanese tradition and culture would be best protected by continuing to confine foreigners to the settlements, rendering the situation still more complex.

The Meiji government exerted great effort to revise the treaties in order to regain sovereignty over the remaining settlements, but one nationalist faction began a movement to insist that on the contrary, Japanese tradition and culture would be best protected by continuing to confine foreigners to the settlements, rendering the situation still more complex.

sen.j: だが、条約改正の実施に伴って、1899年各地の居留地は一斉に回収（返還）された。
sen.e: However, by the revision of the treaty, all of the settlements in Japan were returned together in 1899.
However, with the revision of the treaties, all of the settlements in Japan were restored to Japanese sovereignty together in 1899.
However, with the revision of the treaties, all of the settlements in Japan were restored to Japanese sovereignty together in 1899.

sen.j: 居留地が置かれていた都市の港は居留地時代に大きな発展を遂げ、特に神戸は上海・香港を凌ぐ東洋最大の港へと飛躍していた。
sen.e: The port of the town with the settlement fairly developed during the settlement period, especially Kobe made a jump to the largest port in the Oriental countries, beyond Shanghai and Hong Kong.
The ports of those cities with settlements developed rapidly during the settlement era; Kobe, in particular, leapt ahead of Shanghai and Hong Kong to become the largest port in the Orient.
The ports of those cities with settlements developed rapidly during the settlement period; Kobe, in particular, leapt ahead of Shanghai and Hong Kong to become the largest port in the Orient.
sen.cmt: 時代をperiodで表現してきておりますので、eraをperiodに修正しました。

sen.j: これ以降、外国人は「内地雑居」を認められて旅行制限も解除された。
sen.e: Afterwards, foreigners were allowed 'to live together in town' and travel restriction was lifted.
After the treaties were revised, foreigners were allowed to'live mixed together (with locals) in towns' and travel restrictions were lifted.
After the treaties were revised, foreigners were allowed to'live mixed together (with locals) in towns' and travel restrictions were lifted.

sen.j: ただ、横浜、神戸においては旧居留地を中心とする貿易が続いていた。
sen.e: However, trading was continued mainly in the former settlement in Yokohama and Kobe.
Nonetheless, in Yokohama and Kobe, trade continued to be largely centered around the areas of the former settlements.
Nonetheless, in Yokohama and Kobe, trade continued to be largely centered around the areas of the former settlements.

tit.e: Other Features of the Foreign Settlements
tit.cmt: Inadequate explanation (though it makes perfect sense in Japanese, "other" cannot be used like this in English)
tit.e: Other Features of the Foreign Settlements

sen.j: 例外としてお雇い外国人などは居留地外に居住することもできた。
sen.e: With the exception that employed foreigners could live out of the settlement.
In an exception to the general rule, foreigners with jobs in Japan were allowed to live outside the settlements.
In an exception to the general rule, foreigners with jobs in Japan were allowed to live outside the settlements.

sen.j: 同時期に中国各地の開港場に設置された租界と基本的には同じであり、日本では1920年代頃まで中国における租界も一般的に「居留地」と呼んでいた。
sen.e: Basically the settlement was the same as Sokai (settlement) in China which was established in the every site of opening port at the same period, so that Japan called Sokai in China as 'settlement' by the middle of 1920s.

The foreign settlements in Japan were basically identical to the concessions ("sokai" in Japanese) founded in the treaty ports of China around the same period; as a result, the concessions in China were also generally referred to in Japan as "foreign settlements" until the 1920s.

The foreign settlements in Japan were basically identical to the concessions ("sokai" in Japanese) founded in the treaty ports of China around the same period; as a result, the concessions in China were also generally referred to in Japan as "foreign settlements" until the 1920s.
